specs/juno/restructure-for-plugins.rst.message:
Wondering is it good idea to have an "extension" package. Vendor might want to have a plugin which they don't want to push to upstream? Or external is the right place for such plugin?

Thoughts?

I've seen some projects declare that non-core implementations should be placed in another repository than Barbican. See this Heat wiki for example: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Heat/Plugins  

So we've been thinking there are some plugins that come packaged with Barbican but are still optional and turned off by default...Dogtag is a good example of such a plugin implementation. 

Does that address your concerns though?
But there will be some test code change is the package structure will be change.
Good point, will modify this accordingly.
types *of* plugins

Why external? It seems like if external then where is internal.

What about store/? There could be another SecretStore in the future that runs in software but does not store keys externally.

I was envisioning the layout to be something like:

store/ -- contains secret store interface and all implementations
  store.py -- SecretStore definition
  barbican_hsm.py
  dogtag.py
  kmip.py
  symantec.py
generate/ -- contains generate.py and all implementations for generate
certificate???/ -- probably not best name but probably name of interface

I think my biggest hiccup is with default and external dir names. I don't think those are the most intuitive.

Having the implementations under each interface is problematic for plugins that want to implement more than one type of interface (like dogtag for instance) - which currently implements store and generate and will end up implementing certificate.  Under your layout, files for the dogtag plugin would have to be duplicated - at least insofar as initialization code.

interfaces seems like a nice place to put the contracts that plugins might choose to enforce.

As to default/external - I'm open to different names.  Those were just the first ones that popped to mind.

But the idea of default is for it to be the existing barbican infrastructure (with its second level of stevedore)  The idea would be to take what is currently in crypto and duplicate it essentially unchanged in that location.  That will make the transition to this new structure easier.  Its the "default" implementation if you don't have dogtag or kmip servers.

So could we simplify the structure as follows?:

plugins/
    interfaces/
          (abstract plugin contracts here)
    (plugin implementation modules here)
I would be good with that.

Looks good, just one nit.
can we put one more tab for all .py files, will be good to read.
+1 I just reread it using that formatting and it makes more sense now :)
Correct

Do you mean showing the existing .py files alongside the revised/new ones?
Or just adding a flat list of the revised/new .py files after the indented up there now?

I think he means indenting the .py files so they don't appear to be at the same level as their containing folders.

Like:

folder1/
          file1.py
          file2.py
folder2/
          file3.py
This is listed twice.

More likely than not, we expect to be able to define a base PluginManager that reads a config parameter that determines which plugins are configured, and contains logic to select a plugin for an operation based on whether that plugin supports the relevant operation.

SecretStorePluginManager et, al, are just subclasses of this base class with different config parameters and different operations.  It may make more sense for the definition of these interface -specific plugin managers to occur in the interface file - secret_store.py, certificates.py etc.  This is after all where the various operations are defined.

It seems like we discussed doing that before though, and I recall you had a good argument for placing these lookups in common code (my only concern was never trying to import the crypto or plugin package stuff into common). At any rate, I do like the idea of placing all plugin-related code in the plugins package space.

Why crypto.py?  Why not secret_generate.py perhaps?

Recall that dogtag also implements this plugin.

This crypto.py interface is the lower-level HSM-style encrypt/decrypt interface, akin to the current plugins.py one. Dogtag only implements this interface because it was forced to do so to fit into the current 'crypto' structure. Dogtag really is more naturally fit into secret_store.py contract (which also has generate methods for example), and so would no longer implement this interface.
In line with the proposal above, CryptoPluginManager which would subclass common.PluginManager and would be used for the second level of stevedore would be defined here.
Agreed. So per your comment above, CryptoPluginManager would be found in the interfaces/crypto.py module above I'd think.
dogtag also implements secret_generate interface - at least for symmetric keys right now.  We plan to implement asymmetric key generation in the future, and eventually certificates too.
Yes, and so does the secret_store.py module as I mentioned above.
Out of curiosity, what benefit does this provide over just calling something like getPlugin() and calling the required methods on the plugin? I have not seen this pattern before.
I think it would be better to keep plugin logic inside the plugin namespace.  Maybe this could be plugin/managers.py instead?  I'm not a fan of the catch-all "common" namespace.
This is just bike shedding, but I think "plugin" singular would be better here, as described on line 17

Wondering if it is good idea to have plug-in to address below requirement ?

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/store-master-encryption-key-in-hsm

If yes, does it deserve separate package?
Same as comment above.
I think we should avoid much implementation details in specs

Sorry Nate, I uploaded a patch for Douglas' comment before I noticed yours. Regarding the getPlugin() comment, is that in regards to the resources.py module, vs calling the plugin directly from the api/resource.py? If so, the code in common/resources.py is shared between the API and Worker nodes (which also have generated as well as store secrets).
I commented below.
Douglas, I've moved the plugin manager stuff down into the plugins package below now.

Douglas, regarding 'plugins' vs 'plugin', I'm ok with either. We only have two pluralized package at this level (tests, tasks) vs the others, so maybe 'plugin' is best? Any one object to using 'plugin' here?
I'm good either way. Interfaces is plural too.
Will do, I'll change plugins -> plugin, and interfaces -> interface

Arvind, I think the master key you speak of in the Barbican conf file is only used for the default insecure default plugin. If the HSM was enabled/configured, that would be used for secret storage instead.

Thanks John,

I would appreciate Paul's thoughts on this use case as this is the one we will need.

In case of large scale cloud deployment (e.g. public cloud) with lots (e.g. 10 to the power 8 or more) of users and each user can have at least 2 or more secret (access key, rsa keys). Storing all these secrets in HSM not possible as HSM has limit, it will not allow lots of keys to store on behalf of users.

Usual pattern is to some store master encryption keys (MEK) in HSM and encrypt per tenant encryption keys (KEK) with MEK.  KEK will be stored in key manager database. 
Indeed you have to use production grade crypto library to develop plugin for secrets and KEK generation.

Thoughts?
some store = store some

Arvind, Paul is looking into HSM functionality with reduce key space. I'll defer to him regarding this subject.At any rate, if a new interface is needed, it should be able to find a home in this structure.

So Nate, you'd would prefer for the code block above to be executed directly from the API and Worker nodes? I think with your secret store approach that would probably be possible...the 'shared' logic would now be in plugin implementations such as 'plugins/store_crypto.py'. Does that make sense?

Ya, that's what I was thinking. I was concerned that if common/resources.py has methods like store_key(), get_key(), etc. that is is essentially the same interface as SecretStore, but I'm not sure if that will be the case.

I think a factory method could be good in common/resources.py for retrieving a SecretStore. It could be something like get_secret_store(..) and the parameters would be properties of the secret store that you would like supported.
Sounds good. I figure the follow on CRs for this will refine this a bit, but the basic folder structure above is looking solid enough for this blueprint I think.

Arvind, I would agree with you normally about too much implementation detail, but this blueprint speaks to a significant refactor of Barbican. That said, I think if we can agree on the question above, we should be able to move forward quickly.

config/crd/bases/airship.airshipit.org_s.message: When I see "offset", it sounds like a modification against the range start, not the definition of the range end.  Maybe something like "count" or "number" or something be more clear?
Can we instead use `--service-node-port-range=<start>-<end>` format?  That would be a closer match to the nodeport range definitions that we have in the subcluster networking catalogue already.

The issue is that the `--service-node-port-range=<start>+<offset>` is unfortunately inclusive of the end value, so if we want to substitute in the same value there and here (from the sub-cluster network catalogue), then a "count"/"size"/"number" field won't work. This is why in the sample SipCluster CR I have `offset: 9` since that leads to a round 10 node ports in the range. I agree we can probably make it more clear that this offset relates to the end value and not the start, e.g. "endOffset".
There are some trade offs, but I agree that may be the simplest/fastest way. Done.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Also, when re-running the relinker, we'll only rehash in the expanded range *if we found ourselves needing to make new links*.

swift/cli/relinker.py.message:
Nope, this is the way we want it. The old code needed the check so we could verify that when we (used to!) up-shift the partition with

 for new_part in (2 * partition, 2 * partition + 1):

it'd be in the range that wouldn't be touched by cleanup. Now, all the dirty partitions should already be up-shifted during relink. The old way ran into trouble if you re-ran the relinker: imagine you had

* part power 7, so 128 possible partitions
* parts to process: 123, 45

so we run the relinker once and now have parts

* 123
* 246 (rehashed)
* 247 (rehashed)
* 45
* 90 (invalidated but not rehashed)
* 91 (invalidated but not rehashed)

If we run the relinker *again*, on master we'd rehash 246, 247, 492, 493, 494, and 495, even though those last four don't even make sense with our new part power of 8. On the plus side, with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/781908 we shouldn't go creating mostly-empty partition dirs anymore, but it'd be even better if we never even *tried* to rehash. With *this*, nothing should be rehashed, assuming the initial relink was successful and so no new links were created.

The situation's even hairier if some of those part-123 diskfiles never got relinked and now we're doing the 8 -> 9 part power increase. Replication would have moved them to some other node that doesn't have any 246 or 247 parts, then the relinker will link into 492, 493, 494, and/or 495. With this patch, those will be rehashed, while master will still be rehashing 246 and 247.
This is going to grow and never reset during cleanup currently. We either ought to drop it or reset self.dirty_partitions on cleanup, too.
nit: I'd find it a little easier to read if the partition that the hook is handling was named partition and the dirty partition was named dirty_partition or something else

there doesn't appear to be any test coverage for this part of the change regressing:

  diff --git a/swift/cli/relinker.py b/swift/cli/relinker.py
  index b59e3c154..8510160bd 100644
  --- a/swift/cli/relinker.py
  +++ b/swift/cli/relinker.py
  @@ -204,7 +204,7 @@ class Relinker(object):
           #   |0                             2N|
           #   |                IIJJKKLLMMNNOOPP|
           for partition in self.dirty_partitions:
  -            if self.do_cleanup or partition >= 2 ** (
  +            if partition >= 2 ** (
                       self.states['next_part_power'] - 1):
                   self.diskfile_mgr.get_hashes(
                       device, partition, [], self.policy)
Nice, looks right. If the cleanup has to relink a missing link then make sure we rehash them if they happen to be in the upper region (even though cleanup doesn't look that far).

if we were ever to increase by more than 1 then I think this would need to be 

  self.states['part_power']

worth changing now, just in case?

Actually, cleanup does the rehash *regardless*, since we process partitions in descending order. The expectation is that cleanup should only rarely be doing relinking, though, so it shouldn't matter much.

I had it that way before... 🤔 I *think* I was thinking about what would happen when part_power == next_part_power and whether I'd still be filtering properly -- but then I realized I needed to always do the rehash when cleaning up, anyway.

#willfix
there's no way that post_partition_hook can be skipped (by exception handling) and we still proceed to another partition, correct?

And if we happen to hit a part that has already been rehashed that should be basically no noop right because the cleanup could rehash a newly linked file in the prev_part_power range.

I guess it might have to go check hashes, but shouldn't have to do any hashing.

This should always be doing useful rehashing, unless you were nervous about cleanup and wanted to do a second pass. But yeah, if it's been recently rehashed, the only IO that should be needed will be to load up hashes.pkl and check that hashed.invalid is empty (short of new writes coming in).
"dirty_partitions" -- though maybe I should rename that to something like "linked_into_partitions"....
+1 linked_into_partitions

The 'batch then trickle' is meant to be a trade-off between making progress quickly vs firing off unnecessary requests.

 True
 >>> ec.reconstruct(frags[:4], [0]) == [frags[0]]
 True
 >>> ec.reconstruct(frags[2:], [0]) == [frags[0]]
 True
 >>> ec.reconstruct(frags[:1] + frags[3:], [0]) == [frags[0]]
 True

I guess we log about it (https://github.com/openstack/liberasurecode/blob/master/src/erasurecode.c#L859-L884)... but that seems better than quarantining a frag that has more neighbors out there than we suspected.

if it's a NOOP, we save on CPU, but we're still using network io etc. It'll be nice to just reutrn the found fragment as an iter to ssync then we only need one network connection and save  CPU io too! Though if we have this set up, we might want to start walking handoffs a little... just in case as it too might save us a bunch of work, or finally start tracking last_primary and always check that to make rebalances better.

Something like https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/790374 but cleaned up with better belt and braces checks of course. (and something that has been tested, that hasn't even been run, just thought a patch would be easier to read then a paste diff).

This frag is counted against quarantine_threshold - see test_reconstruct_fa_no_quarantine_more_than_threshold_frags

num_responses is the condition, not number of useful_responses
Oh, interesting... so if we've got a 2x(4+2) policy, quarantine threshold of 1, and we can only find the two copies of frag index 0 (say), we'll still quarantine...

No. Adding a unit test to cover this: the duplicate frag will prevent quarantine. In general my approach has been to only quarantine in the scenario we understand and 'expect'. We can always relax the conditions in future.
Or, neighbor frags will get reverted from handoffs to *other* nodes and we'll discover we *do* have enough to reconstruct.

Yeah, I think I prefer returning the bucket here, even if we're not moving the needle on useful_responses. Matches the documented return better, and both of the callers have an explicit check on number of useful responses after they get a bucket in hand.

specs/xena/explicit-default-routes.rst.message: nit: But never a mixture...
Done
To have the same usability worth to think about adding the same default route (as in "implicit" mode) as extraroute during gw port addition.

I interpreted your idea as keeping the same behavior (of installing a default route) in explicit mode as we had in implicit mode. But this time together with the corresponding extra route record. So the switch from implicit to explicit would not actually change the routing table, only the list of extra routes.

I really liked the idea first, but then I started to realize two things:

1) If we do this, the user still cannot uniformly manage all default routes. One default route will occasionally be managed through the external gateway networks gateway_ip. The rest through explicit extra routes.

2) This may have a bit more complex implementation, because we need to consider the case when the removal of the original default route's extra route overrides the external gateway networks gateway_ip.

So now I slightly lean to keep the original proposal.

What do you think?

what in the case when router has gateway_ip and user will update it to be explicit_default_routes=True? Will gateway_ip be removed? Or it will be still set but will have no effect anymore?

And similar question applies to the creation of router too - what if user will do something like:

    neutron router-create R1 --explicit_default_routes True

will it set gateway_ip of not at all?
correct. I somehow mixed things here. "gateway_ip" is set for subnet, not for router. Sorry for the noise here.

By 'gateway_ip' do you mean the router's external gw's subnet's gateway_ip?

This gateway_ip is unfortunately not the attribute of the router, but of another API object. Because of that indirect connection I think changing it could be surprising to the user and I'd like to avoid that.

On the other hand I believe if a user sets explicit mode knowingly that user is not going to be surprised if the gateway_ip is there, but it is ignored.

Imagine the case when I have router with explicit_default_routes=False and some gateway ip. It is configured as default route in router's namespace. Now I update router to be explicit_default_routes=True but there is no any route to 0/0 in extraroutes yet - will my default route which is using gateway_ip be deleted from the router's namespace or not?

"clarity" sounds good for me 😊 So I would also go that way but be sure to warn users in our docs (like e.g. api-ref) that setting "explicit_default_router=True" on existing router may break connectivity to/from vms behind that router and addition of the new extra route may be needed to fix it.

This question overlaps with a question from Lajos, please see my answer there too:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/781475/1/specs/xena/explicit-default-routes.rst#59

I believe there's a tradeoff here: If we keep the default route when switching to explicit mode, then there's one less API call to make.

On the other hand if we start with an empty set of default routes when switching to explicit mode, that provides more clarity and uniformity in managing the default routes in explicit mode:
/1/ because no default route can be managed in two ways (via the external gw's subnet's gateway_ip and via an extra route),
/2/ because we don't need to map those two ways to each other (for example to implicitly change one extra route when the user updates the gateway_ip or the other way around)

At the moment I lean to preferring the clarity.

However I also realized that we may need to switch to explicit mode without interrupting traffic so I added an exception here to allow that.

Changing the explicit_default_routes from False to True will remove the existing default route by default implicitly?

I mean if users run router in traditional mode (current mode), they do not change the default route. But if set explicit_default_routes=True, the default route will gone? Then all traffic will get broken?
Please see my answer at line 68.

Same to the question in line 59, then what? That "one default route with the same nexthop as in implicit mode" will be deleted?
If yes, then traffic down? But why?

I added this exception to avoid the traffic down situation. But I forgot to also update lines 58-59. I rearranged these paragraphs a bit. Now I hope it's consistent and allows switching to explicit mode without traffic down.

nit: Using "_" as a throwaway variable is not a good practice.
"_" has many meanings in python: unused variable, i18n, last value, etc.
Example: https://github.com/openstack/designate/blob/master/designate/objects/base.py#L19

When you can, it is best to index the result instead of using "_", for example:
zone = self.client.create_zone()[1]

The "addCleanup" call should come directly after the "create_" call to make sure the cleanup gets registered should there be an error.
As this is written, if for some reason the zone did not have a "pool_id", the test would fail and the zone would not get cleaned up.
Instead of sorting these, you can use self.assertCountEqual

the other tests use this style to grab the body:
_, zone = self.client.create_zone(
              zone_type=const.SECONDARY_ZONE_TYPE, primaries=nameservers)

Yes I'm agree, this is a bit confusing, but we do want to use a syntax used in this patch instead of the old manner as you've found and here is why:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/octavia-tempest-plugin/+/777742/4/octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/v2/test_traffic_ops.py


Michael Johnson
Mar 03
We don't use "_" as a throw away variable in Octavia. It is a bad practice and leads to errors.
"_" has multiple meanings in python, including being used for I18n. This causes linting failures as well as potential runtime issues.
The best practice is to use the index like Arkady did here.

etc/object-server.conf-sample.message: This condition doesn't seem particularly useful -- I'd wager in most clusters 90%+ of fragments are older than a reclaim age. We may still want the condition as a practical matter, but calling it out in the config docs seems like it could confuse the issue, its causes, and why an operator should feel OK about quarantining this data.

I included reclaim_age in the conditions because it is relevant to how we understand the frags to have become lonely, and how quarantine is the only future for the frag. Younger frags *shouldn't* be lonely. 

Also, with low cardinality EC data/parity it is more likely we have a frag on a primary and tombstones on handoffs, and I'd prefer to let the tombstones be reverted and eventually have the frag deleted by 'normal' means, rather than prematurely quarantine it.

I take your point about possibly 'too much information' in the doc, but ops could be equally confused if they see the logs, set the threshold to non-zero, but still see the logs, unless they understand there is a time component to the quarantining. I'll try rewording it.
Hmm... we only have per-policy config options for the proxy server currently, is that right?
correct. I did go down the path of plumbing in per-policy config for this, but backed off for now while we take some first steps.
So a new term, in the proxy we have request_node_count, I wonder if we could use the same name or even mechanism, just so we don't have to keep having special options.

Yeah I understand. You could get the same with the request_count as it stands, ie:

  2 * replicas

I guess would be the same as `1 batch`. As the first 1 * replica is taken up by the primaries.
I'll ponder this some more - I do agree that the fewer concepts that ops need to understand the better

I went with batches rather than an absolute node count because it adapts better across different policies - per-policy config would be the ideal but maybe overly complex for this issue - so the idea is that the handoff count scales with the policy frag count.

So this is kinda weird, and I haven't dug into it enough to figure out what happened, but: While I was exercising the handoff-handling, I

* took a standard 8-disk SAIO with a 4+2 EC policy,
* shut down one of the nodes (1.conf) that had two assignments,
* uploaded an object,
* found a node (4.conf) with one primary and one handoff frag and deleted all other frags, then finally
* ran the reconstructor with quarantine_threshold=1.

Nothing got quarantined (which was good!) but I got some log lines like

 object-6040: Unable to get enough responses (2/4) to reconstruct durable 127.0.0.3:6030/sdb3/191/AUTH_test/c/.profile policy#0 frag#3 with ETag 0d2bebbf5990a90ba0d8af0534cf4f32 and timestamp 1618871492.48811
 object-6040: Unable to get enough responses (3 error responses) to reconstruct durable 127.0.0.3:6030/sdb3/191/AUTH_test/c/.profile policy#0 frag#3

which seems weird -- it seems to indicate that we only made 5 requests? I expected 7 (i.e. 5 errors).

the first batch of requests returned 2 frags and 3 errors (no request is made to the primary that we're rebuilding to). The 2 frags is already above the quarantine_threshold of 1, so the second set of requests to handoffs wasn't made.

I do wonder if the logging could be better here e.g. get all the info on one log line, and detail what status codes were returned.

Note: we've never tried handoffs for the purposes of rebuilding alone - now the handoffs are tried for the purpose of quarantining, but as a consequence we might now end up rebuilding from handoffs....I guess we could choose to *not* do that rebuild from handoffs, just prevent the quarantine and move on, and leave the handoffs to revert, but then we might end up needing to do the rebuild anyway once all the frags have found their way to primaries???

manifests/site/virtual-network-cloud/tar.message:
Do we need to have a different controlplane image for subclusters, or can we replace the existing definition from versions-airshipctl into the subcluster m3machinetemplate?  That would remove a bit of duplication if that's a good fit.

If the replacement rules sourced from versions-airshipctl, then we'd always be able to patch that catalogue at the subcluster level if we needed to override what's being used in the target cluster.

On the other hand, if we know that we'll typically need one qcow for the target cluster, and a different qcow for all subclusters, then the way you have it is probably the best bet.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: We talked about maybe switching to orjson at some point for performance reasons. Switching to yaml we would not benefit from that. Not sure how relevant that would be for the build requests though.

I'm not sure if we should switch the entire job request to yaml. Since we use json for all machine to machine communication this feels wrong and likely comes with a performance drawback.  https://storage.gra.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_0f8/789087/3/check/puppet-cinder-tripleo-standalone/0f85340/logs/undercloud/etc/puppet/hieradata/service_configs.json

ok, the post_migration checks here wont block the initial system modify -m

        # Skip if the flag is not set or if the system mode is not set to duplex
        if (not system.capabilities.get('simplex_to_duplex_migration') or

        host = self.dbapi.ihost_get(self.host_uuid)

When relinker first starts, should it reset *all* devices? otherwise there's a start up period when the recon would show devices with all parts done when in fact no parts are done.

That would ideally means coupling the reset of recon with a reset of the state files, which the relinker doesn't yet do (but should).

But during start up the recon stats could be updated from the states file so that if the state file has been reset by another process then recon reflects that. In hook_pre_device maybe? Or maybe sooner - if the relinker process is running over more than one device then we'd need all the devices to have their recon info reset early in the process. But only if it's a fresh start, not if the relinker is picking up from where it left off previous progress.

Bottom line is that when the relinker process starts it needs to make sure that current recon info reflects what is in the state file.

Yeah, agreed with Rabi here. Perhaps we should phrase this differently. We can describe that we will publish what is tested and which interfaces are intended to be used and specifically what is not intended to be used as an external interface.

I think we need to look at the framework like a library or an API. A well documented code library or API publishes a specification of what is supported, and often examples on how to use it. I think we should focus on the aspect of publishing the supported framework interface. That's what I was going for here with this point, and I'll attempt to clarify.

Functionally, what we document as supported I think that lives somewhere else. For example, deploying a given cinder driver may not be supported. That's separate from documenting the supported interface for the framework.
From experience, the way interfaces have grown unabated, I think we need to clearly defined what 'kind of' interfaces won't be supported.

> I would suggest to document what is not officially supported only.

Perhaps this should be rephrased then. Listing all that supported can be not infinite but a huge list. Maybe we should only document that is tested? And claimed that everything else is not supported.
IMO I'd keep this statement as is. Document what is supported but if necessary call out whatever is explicitly forbidden. Only calling out what is not supported could in theory be an infinite list.
This is not always *easy* and may not always be possible, like deploying Nova without Keystone and rabbitmq with mysql

I think limits like serial restarts is likely at a task level. Where we put timeouts, caps on execution and parallelization as part of a task definition within a service.  We're aware of these types of restrictions and they should likely be expressed in the task schema and orchestration tool.

The restarts need to be able to be expressed in such a way that they can be sequential (one host at a time) or simultaneous (all at once).

Some services we'll be deploying can be updating in a rolling sequence (eg: nova), whereas others (eg: neutron) need to be updated simultaneously.

We may also have to express groupings for this behaviour. eg: neutron server needs to restart all at once, whereas neutron agents should restart in sequence.

This perhaps belongs in Non-principles below.

Perhaps something worth adding somewhere is a security principle which should apply, and that is to deploy the smallest amount of things required to meet the requirements of a functional system. This is how we reduce the attack surface, but also how we reduce the potential for system conflicts.
Indeed - I'm also trying to involve Security ppl for that specific point

This is the one that still bugs me a little bit.

We have 'HardwareSoftwareSeparation' which specifies that hardware bootstrapping is out of scope. It's not clear to me what exactly that means - are we talking about bootstrapping disk arrays and such there?

To me, base OS provisioning is something else that should be scoped as an independent tool too. The deployment framework should expect a base OS with certain properties (specific bridges pre-setup, specific hypervisor properties, etc). So that everything it deploys can just plug into that as a consistent interface. This also really helps us to decouple the two for testing and deployment.

We currently have a built-in provisioning system and a way of deploying over a pre-installed system. I'm thinking we could have a single interface which always assumes that it's pre-deployed... we don't care if it's metalsmith, foreman, satellite, or <insert homegrown provisioning system here>.

What we expect from the pre-provisioned base OS should be well defined and treated like any other API. This really helps us to scope our decisions properly about what we do in the deployment framework, how we handle changes in that interface for upgrades, etc.

This is meant to mean that TripleO can bootstrap the cloud deployment starting with a base OS. There aren't other areas where we talk about hardware bootstrapping.

HardwareSoftwareSeparation refers to separation from  OS provisioning (aka, what Ironic does). Can we fine tune that wording? Technically, it's all software because we aren't automating robots to rack hardware or plug in gear. However, we do want a clear handoff from the OS to the services we will deploy on top of the OS. That way however the OS got there can be abstracted (Ironic/libvirt/cloud/etc). Perhaps HardwareSoftwareSeparation would be better stated as OperatingSystemSeparation?

I would clarify it further as saying that the framework expects as base os, minimal os, or cloud image. we should stay away from specifics, but we could give examples (rhel or centos cloud image, rhel minimal, etc).

Anything beyond what you get with the defaults from those images or their installers, needs to be implemented as a service.

Your comments about assuming everything is predeployed is exactly what was done in wallaby. The integration with metalsmith via our CLI lives under the TripleO project, but I don't consider that as part of the deployment framework that we are defining here.
maybe it should be changed to initial setup of required packages. And maybe repos as well (but that's perhaps belongs to provisioning of HW?)

I feel like this needs some expanding... something like:


#. [ProvisioningSeparation] Separation between hardware provisioning,
   base OS provisioning and software configuration.

   #. Baremetal configuration, network configuration and base operating system
      provisioning is decoupled from the software deployment.
   #. The software deployment will have a defined set of minimal requirements
      which are expected to be in-place before it begins the software deployment.
      Examples of requirements include specific linux distributions, specific
      linux distribution versions, password-less access via ssh, password-less
      sudo access, a list of pre-configured network bridges, etc.
i like it! added.
